cot.content:
To solve the problem, Please think and reason step by step, then answer.
question:
who was the drummer with the travelling wilburys
        
Generation Format:
Reasoning process:
Answer:

Reasoning process: The Traveling Wilburys were a supergroup formed in the late 1980s, consisting of several well-known musicians. The group included Bob Dylan, George Harrison, Jeff Lynne, Roy Orbison, and Tom Petty. While they had a collaborative approach to their music, they did not have a dedicated drummer in the traditional sense. Instead, they often used session musicians for drumming on their recordings. However, in live performances and some recordings, Jim Keltner, a well-known session drummer, played with them. 

Answer: The Traveling Wilburys did not have a dedicated drummer, but Jim Keltner played drums on some of their recordings.

anchoring.content:
You are a cognitive scientist, to answer the following question:
who was the drummer with the travelling wilburys
I will provide you with several retrieved passages:
Passages:
['The Traveling Wilburys (sometimes shortened to the Wilburys) were an English–American supergroup consisting of Bob Dylan, George Harrison, Jeff Lynne, Roy Orbison and Tom Petty. Originating from an idea discussed by Harrison and Lynne during the sessions for Harrison\'s 1987 album "Cloud Nine", the band formed in April 1988 after the five members united to record a bonus track for Harrison\'s next European single. When this collaboration, "Handle with Care", was deemed too good for such a limited release, the group agreed to record a full album, titled "Traveling Wilburys Vol. 1". Following Orbison\'s death in December 1988, the band released a second album, which they titled "Traveling Wilburys Vol. 3", in 1990.\n', 'The Traveling Wilburys Vol. 1 is the debut studio album by the English-American supergroup Traveling Wilburys, comprising George Harrison, Jeff Lynne, Bob Dylan, Roy Orbison and Tom Petty. It was released in October 1988 to commercial success and critical acclaim. Although Harrison had long planned to start such a band, the project came about through happenstance. Harrison was in Los Angeles and in need of a B-side for a single from his "Cloud Nine" album, which resulted in the participants collaborating informally on the song "Handle with Care" at Dylan\'s home. Adopting alter egos as the five Wilbury brothers, they then recorded a full album, produced by Lynne and Harrison.\n', 'BULLET::::- Jim Keltner, drummer for the Traveling Wilburys\n', 'The Traveling Wilburys\n', 'The Traveling Wilburys consisted of four notable singers with decades of success behind them - George Harrison (The Beatles), Tom Petty (Tom Petty and the Heartbreakers), Jeff Lynne (ELO) and Bob Dylan. "The Traveling Wilburys Collection" was a boxset of their two studio albums ("Traveling Wilburys Vol. 1" and "Traveling Wilburys Vol. 3"), neither of which reached the top ten on their first release in 1988 and 1990 respectively.\n', 'BULLET::::- Traveling Wilburys, a band featuring Tom Petty, frequent Petty collaborator Jeff Lynne, George Harrison, Roy Orbison and Bob Dylan\n', 'Section::::Musical career.:1987–91: Traveling Wilburys.\n', 'George Harrison and Jeff Lynne first discussed the idea for the Traveling Wilburys in early 1987 when they were recording "Cloud Nine", Harrison\'s first album in five years. When Harrison suggested they should form their "dream" band, Lynne chose Roy Orbison as a potential bandmate, while Harrison\'s first choice was Bob Dylan. Lynne later said that, although he thought Harrison was "just joking", "Anything could happen with George, everybody loved him." The pair devised the term "wilbury" in response to mishaps occurring during the recording process that led to them having to "bury" the unwanted sound in the mix. In April 1988, after Warner Bros. Records had asked Harrison for an additional track for the European release of "This Is Love", the third single from "Cloud Nine", he and Lynne, together with Dylan, Orbison and Tom Petty, rush-recorded "Handle with Care". The song was deemed by Warner\'s to be too good for such a limited release. Mo Ostin, the company\'s chairman, instead encouraged Harrison to form the group he had long spoken of and record an album.\n', 'Traveling Wilburys Vol. 3 is the second and final studio album by the Traveling Wilburys, a group consisting of George Harrison, Jeff Lynne, Bob Dylan and Tom Petty. It was released on October 29, 1990 as the follow-up to their 1988 debut, "Traveling Wilburys Vol. 1". The band members again adopted pseudonyms for their contributions, using new names from the fictitious Wilbury brothers.\n', 'In the Rolling Stone Press book "The New Rolling Stone Encyclopedia of Rock & Roll", the Traveling Wilburys are described as "the ultimate supergroup", with a line-up that represented four eras of rock music history and included "three indisputable gods" in Dylan, Harrison and Orbison. The editors also recognise the band as "the antithesis of a supergroup", however, due to the musicians\' adoption of fraternal alter egos and the humour inherent in the project. AllMusic managing editor Stephen Thomas Erlewine has similarly written: "It\'s impossible to picture a supergroup with a stronger pedigree than that (all that\'s missing is a Rolling Stone), but in another sense it\'s hard to call the Wilburys a true supergroup, since they arrived nearly two decades after the all-star craze of the \'70s peaked, and they never had the self-important air of nearly all the other supergroups. That, of course, was the key to their charm …" Speaking to music journalist Paul Zollo in 2004, Petty agreed that humour and self-effacement had been key factors in the Wilburys\' success, adding: "We wanted to make something good in a world that seemed to get uglier and uglier and meaner and meaner … And I\'m really proud that I was part of it. Because I do think that it brought a little sunshine into the world."\n']

', 'Traveling Wilburys Vol. 3 is the second and final studio album by the Traveling Wilburys, a group consisting of George Harrison, Jeff Lynne, Bob Dylan and Tom Petty. It was released on October 29, 1990 as the follow-up to their 1988 debut, "Traveling Wilburys Vol. 1". The band members again adopted pseudonyms for their contributions, using new names from the fictitious Wilbury brothers.
', 'In the Rolling Stone Press book "The New Rolling Stone Encyclopedia of Rock & Roll", the Traveling Wilburys are described as "the ultimate supergroup", with a line-up that represented four eras of rock music history and included "three indisputable gods" in Dylan, Harrison and Orbison. The editors also recognise the band as "the antithesis of a supergroup", however, due to the musicians' adoption of fraternal alter egos and the humour inherent in the project. AllMusic managing editor Stephen Thomas Erlewine has similarly written: "It's impossible to picture a supergroup with a stronger pedigree than that (all that's missing is a Rolling Stone), but in another sense it's hard to call the Wilburys a true supergroup, since they arrived nearly two decades after the all-star craze of the '70s peaked, and they never had the self-important air of nearly all the other supergroups. That, of course, was the key to their charm …" Speaking to music journalist Paul Zollo in 2004, Petty agreed that humour and self-effacement had been key factors in the Wilburys' success, adding: "We wanted to make something good in a world that seemed to get uglier and uglier and meaner and meaner … And I'm really proud that I was part of it. Because I do think that it brought a little sunshine into the world."
']

question_info.question: who was the drummer with the travelling wilburys
passages:
The Traveling Wilburys (sometimes shortened to the Wilburys) were an English–American supergroup consisting of Bob Dylan, George Harrison, Jeff Lynne, Roy Orbison and Tom Petty. Originating from an idea discussed by Harrison and Lynne during the sessions for Harrison's 1987 album "Cloud Nine", the band formed in April 1988 after the five members united to record a bonus track for Harrison's next European single. When this collaboration, "Handle with Care", was deemed too good for such a limited release, the group agreed to record a full album, titled "Traveling Wilburys Vol. 1". Following Orbison's death in December 1988, the band released a second album, which they titled "Traveling Wilburys Vol. 3", in 1990.
The Traveling Wilburys Vol. 1 is the debut studio album by the English-American supergroup Traveling Wilburys, comprising George Harrison, Jeff Lynne, Bob Dylan, Roy Orbison and Tom Petty. It was released in October 1988 to commercial success and critical acclaim. Although Harrison had long planned to start such a band, the project came about through happenstance. Harrison was in Los Angeles and in need of a B-side for a single from his "Cloud Nine" album, which resulted in the participants collaborating informally on the song "Handle with Care" at Dylan's home. Adopting alter egos as the five Wilbury brothers, they then recorded a full album, produced by Lynne and Harrison.
BULLET::::- Jim Keltner, drummer for the Traveling Wilburys
The Traveling Wilburys
The Traveling Wilburys consisted of four notable singers with decades of success behind them - George Harrison (The Beatles), Tom Petty (Tom Petty and the Heartbreakers), Jeff Lynne (ELO) and Bob Dylan. "The Traveling Wilburys Collection" was a boxset of their two studio albums ("Traveling Wilburys Vol. 1" and "Traveling Wilburys Vol. 3"), neither of which reached the top ten on their first release in 1988 and 1990 respectively.
BULLET::::- Traveling Wilburys, a band featuring Tom Petty, frequent Petty collaborator Jeff Lynne, George Harrison, Roy Orbison and Bob Dylan
Section::::Musical career.:1987–91: Traveling Wilburys.
George Harrison and Jeff Lynne first discussed the idea for the Traveling Wilburys in early 1987 when they were recording "Cloud Nine", Harrison's first album in five years. When Harrison suggested they should form their "dream" band, Lynne chose Roy Orbison as a potential bandmate, while Harrison's first choice was Bob Dylan. Lynne later said that, although he thought Harrison was "just joking", "Anything could happen with George, everybody loved him." The pair devised the term "wilbury" in response to mishaps occurring during the recording process that led to them having to "bury" the unwanted sound in the mix. In April 1988, after Warner Bros. Records had asked Harrison for an additional track for the European release of "This Is Love", the third single from "Cloud Nine", he and Lynne, together with Dylan, Orbison and Tom Petty, rush-recorded "Handle with Care". The song was deemed by Warner's to be too good for such a limited release. Mo Ostin, the company's chairman, instead encouraged Harrison to form the group he had long spoken of and record an album.
Traveling Wilburys Vol. 3 is the second and final studio album by the Traveling Wilburys, a group consisting of George Harrison, Jeff Lynne, Bob Dylan and Tom Petty. It was released on October 29, 1990 as the follow-up to their 1988 debut, "Traveling Wilburys Vol. 1". The band members again adopted pseudonyms for their contributions, using new names from the fictitious Wilbury brothers.
In the Rolling Stone Press book "The New Rolling Stone Encyclopedia of Rock & Roll", the Traveling Wilburys are described as "the ultimate supergroup", with a line-up that represented four eras of rock music history and included "three indisputable gods" in Dylan, Harrison and Orbison. The editors also recognise the band as "the antithesis of a supergroup", however, due to the musicians' adoption of fraternal alter egos and the humour inherent in the project. AllMusic managing editor Stephen Thomas Erlewine has similarly written: "It's impossible to picture a supergroup with a stronger pedigree than that (all that's missing is a Rolling Stone), but in another sense it's hard to call the Wilburys a true supergroup, since they arrived nearly two decades after the all-star craze of the '70s peaked, and they never had the self-important air of nearly all the other supergroups. That, of course, was the key to their charm …" Speaking to music journalist Paul Zollo in 2004, Petty agreed that humour and self-effacement had been key factors in the Wilburys' success, adding: "We wanted to make something good in a world that seemed to get uglier and uglier and meaner and meaner … And I'm really proud that I was part of it. Because I do think that it brought a little sunshine into the world."
